hints_html:
Use partial fractions.

Since the denominator can not be simplified any further you will need a polynomial of degree one in the enumerator of the \(\frac1{x^2+4}\) term.
hints_latex:
Since the denominator can not be simplified any further you will need a
polynomial of degree one in the enumerator of the $\frac1{x^2+4}$ term.
hints_raw:
Use partial fractions.
Since the denominator can not be simplified any further you will need a polynomial of degree one in the enumerator of the <math>\frac1{x^2+4}</math> term.
question: 3 (c)
sols_html:
We want to write the integrand using partial fractions:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{{\color{red}4}x+{\color{blue}8}}{(x-2)(x^2+4)}&=\frac{A}{x-2}+\frac{Bx+C}{x^2+4} \\&=\frac{A(x^2+4)+(Bx+C)(x-2)}{(x-2)(x^2+4)} \\ &=\frac{Ax^2 {\color{blue}+ 4A}+Bx^2{\color{red}+ C}x {\color{red}- 2B}x {\color{blue}- 2C}}{(x-2)(x^2+4)} \\&= \frac{(A+B)x^2 + {\color{red}(-2B+C)}x + {\color{blue}4A-2C}}{(x-2)(x^2+4)}\end{aligned}\]

Comparing coefficients we get the equations:

\[\begin{aligned} 0&=A+B \\ \color{red} 4 &\color{red}=-2B+C \\\color{blue} 8&\color{blue}=4A-2C\end{aligned}\]

Now we solve

\[\begin{aligned} A=-B,\end{aligned}\]

which gives \(4=2A+C\), adding twice this equation to the third one we get \(16=8A\) so \(A=2\). This means \(B=-2\) and \(C=0\).

So we have

\[\begin{aligned} \int \frac{4x+8}{(x-2)(x^2+4)}dx&=2\int \frac{1}{x-2}dx-\int \frac{2x}{x^2+4}dx\\ &=2\ln|x-2|-\ln|x^2+4|+c\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
We want to write the integrand using partial fractions:

:<math>
\begin{align}
\frac{{\color{red}4}x+{\color{blue}8}}{(x-2)(x^2+4)}&=\frac{A}{x-2}+\frac{Bx+C}{x^2+4} \\
&=\frac{A(x^2+4)+(Bx+C)(x-2)}{(x-2)(x^2+4)} \\
&=\frac{Ax^2 {\color{blue}+ 4A}+Bx^2{\color{red}+ C}x {\color{red}- 2B}x {\color{blue}- 2C}}{(x-2)(x^2+4)} \\
&= \frac{(A+B)x^2 + {\color{red}(-2B+C)}x + {\color{blue}4A-2C}}{(x-2)(x^2+4)}
\end{align}
</math>

Comparing coefficients we get the equations:

:<math>
\begin{align}
0&=A+B \\
\color{red} 4 &\color{red}=-2B+C \\
\color{blue} 8&\color{blue}=4A-2C
\end{align}</math>

Now we solve: <math>A=-B</math>, which gives <math>4=2A+C</math>, adding twice this equation to the third one we get <math> 16=8A </math> so <math>A=2</math>. This means <math>B=-2</math> and <math>C=0</math>.

So we have 

:<math>
\begin{align}
\int \frac{4x+8}{(x-2)(x^2+4)}dx&=2\int \frac{1}{x-2}dx-\int \frac{2x}{x^2+4}dx\\
&=2\ln|x-2|-\ln|x^2+4|+c
\end{align}
</math>
